list.title: Question 1
list.content: Which statement isnottrue about the genome?A.\hspace{1em}The human genome is organised into chromosomes.B.\hspace{1em}Each liver cell contains a full copy of the genome.C.\hspace{1em}Organisms of the same species share most of their genome.D.\hspace{1em}All the information carried by the genome is expressed in each cell.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Not all genes are expressed in each cell. Only the necessary genes are expressed based on the specialised function of the cell.Choice Disnota true statement, and so is the correct answer.The genome is all the genetic information of an organism, including the genes and non-coding DNA. In humans, the genome is organised into linear chromosomes in the nucleus, and circular chromosomes in the mitochondria.Choice Ais a true statement and so an incorrect answer. Organisms of the same species have most of their genome in common; however, variations give rise to some diversity between individuals.Choice Cis a true statement and so an incorrect answer. Each cell in a multicellular organism typically contains a full copy of the genome, including liver cells, an exception is red blood cells as they do not have a nucleus.Choice Bis a true statement and so an incorrect answer.

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
The scientific name for the little spotted kiwi isApteryx owenii. Which of the species below is most closely related to the little spotted kiwi?

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9878cab2-bbf6-4ef3-affc-520f8a700b10/images/6faa3925-6492-47de-90a7-925e1e8a2859/BI1227.png)

[Source: Adapted from Lapsley Miller, J. (2023, August 28).Little Spotted Kiwi. Wikipedia. Retrieved September 13, 2023, from https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Little_spotted_kiwi.  Copyright under CC BY-SA 4.0]A.\hspace{1em}Apteryx australisB.\hspace{1em}Little spotted pardaloteC.\hspace{1em}Owenii apteryxD.\hspace{1em}Neognathae owenii
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Species names are given using the binomial system, where the genus comes first, and the species follows. Species with the same genus have similar traits and are closely related;Choice Ais correct.Choice Bis incorrect as it is not a scientific name, so conveys no information about the relatedness of species.Choice Cis incorrect as it is just a reversal of the scientific name of the little spotted kiwi, and is in a different genus.Choice Dis incorrect as it is not in the same genus as the little spotted kiwi.

list.title: Question 3
list.content: What is the best definition for a species?A.\hspace{1em}A group of individuals living in a defined area.B.\hspace{1em}A group of individuals of the same species living and interacting with one another in a given area.C.\hspace{1em}A group of individuals living in a given area and interacting within the environment.D.\hspace{1em}A group of individuals that can interbreed and produce fertile offspring.
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:A group of individuals living in a defined area is not a biological definition (Choice A).  A group of individuals of the same species living in a given area at the same time who are interacting with each other is a population (Choice B) and the environment in which they live is a habitat (Choice C). It is only when they can interbreed to produce fertile offspring that they can be considered a species. (Choice D).

list.title: Question 4
list.content:
The table shows the nucleotide base sequence and genome size (number of base pairs, bp) for different species.

![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/129076a1-8fb2-48be-8b41-09d19f5d4455/images/e50f84c7-31b6-4770-bdd6-a3ae9bb089f4/BI0840.png)

[©Revision Village 2023. ]Which conclusion can be drawn, based on the table and your own knowledge?A.\hspace{1em}Genome size is proportional to the size of the species.B.\hspace{1em}The more closely related two species are, the more similar their base sequences.C.\hspace{1em}Humans have more genes than chimpanzees, mice and horses.D.\hspace{1em}The base sequence in the table for humans and chimpanzees is the same, therefore they have an identical genetic code.
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Species that share a recent common ancestor, such as humans and chimpanzees, are more likely to have similar base sequences. Over time, as species diverge and evolve, mutations accumulate in their base sequences. The longer two species have been separated from their common ancestor, the more mutations will have accumulated in their genomes. Therefore, species that are closely related have fewer accumulated mutations and more similar base sequences (Choice B).Choice Ais incorrect because genome size is not necessarily proportional to the size of the species. The genome size can vary significantly even among organisms of similar size, and organisms with similar-sized genomes, such as the horse and mouse vary greatly in size.Choice Cis incorrect because it is possible to have a larger genome size with a comparable, or even smaller, number of genes, depending on the amount of non-coding DNA and repetitive sequences present in the genome. Humans have a larger genome but a similar number of genes to the chimpanzee, mouse and horse.Choice Dis incorrect because there is a difference of one nucleotide base in the table between humans and chimpanzees. The genome of humans and chimpanzees is similar but not the same.

list.title: Question 5
list.content:
Biologists use the binomial naming system to name every organism on the planet. The binomial name for the platypus isOrnithorhynchus anatinus. Which statement(s) below are true for the binomial naming system and the platypus?I.\hspace{1em}The genus for the platypus isOrnithorhynchus.II.\hspace{.7em}The binomial naming system is based on an international agreement
between scientists.III.\hspace{.4em}The name,Ornithorhynchus anatinusis unique to platypus species.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:All three statements are correct. The first part of the binomial name is the genus, the second part is the species which is unique to platypus species. The binomial system and binomial names are agreed between biologists at international congresses.

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Which of the following is the correct format for species names according to the binomial naming system?A.\hspace{1em}Genus + SpeciesB.\hspace{1em}Genus + speciesC.\hspace{1em}Genus+speciesD.\hspace{1em}Genus+Species
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because only the genus name should be capitalised, it should come before the species name, and both should be in italics.Choices AandDare incorrect because only the genus name should be capitalised.Choice Bis incorrect, as the genus and species name should be in italics.

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Whole genome sequencing has been used to sequence the genomes of many species. Which of the following are potential future uses of whole genome sequencing?A.\hspace{1em}Identifying disease-causing alleles.B.\hspace{1em}Sequencing the genomes of bacteria and fungi.C.\hspace{1em}Advancing personalised medicine.D.\hspace{1em}Identifying evolutionary relationships between species.
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because personalised medicine is a potential future application of whole genome sequencing. While it is not yet widely available, the continued study of individual genomes could lead to treatments tailored to an individual’s genetic profile, improving the effectiveness of medical interventions.Choice Ais incorrect because whole genome sequencing has already been used to identify disease-causing alleles which is improving understanding of genetic diseases.Choice Bis incorrect because whole genome sequencing is currently being used to sequence the genomes of disease-causing bacteria and viruses.Choice Dis incorrect because whole genome sequencing of a range of species is currently being used to identify evolutionary relationships and common ancestors; it is not a novel use.

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Which of the following is true for the biological species concept?A.\hspace{1em}Organisms within the same species can interbreed to produce fertile offspringB.\hspace{1em}Organisms within the same species can interbreed to produce infertile offspringC.\hspace{1em}Species are groups of organisms with shared traitsD.\hspace{1em}Species are groups of organisms without shared traits
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:According to the biological species concept, a species is a group of organisms that can interbreed to produce fertile offspring.Choice Ais correct.Choice Bis incorrect as it refers to infertile offspring.Choices CandDare incorrect because they refer to the morphological species concept.

list.title: Question 9
list.content: What determines the overall size of a eukaryotic genome?A.\hspace{1em}The number of genesB.\hspace{1em}The number of chromosomesC.\hspace{1em}The amount of proteinD.\hspace{1em}The total amount of DNA
list.markScheme: DExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The number of genes contributes to the overall size of the genome, but it is not the sole determinant. Eukaryotic genomes contain a significant amount of noncoding DNA.  The amount of this non-coding DNA is a major contributing factor to the overall size of a eukaryotic genome.Choice Ais incorrect.Chromosomes vary greatly in the number of genes and noncoding DNA they contain. Simply knowing the number of chromosomes in a genome does little to describe the size of the genome.Choice Bis incorrect.Choice Cis incorrect because a genome is a measure of only the amount of DNA and does not consider protein.Choice Dis the correct choice because it is the total amount of DNA in a genome that determines the size of that genome, regardless of the function of the DNA.

list.title: Question 10
list.content: The okapi looks like a small-sized giraffe and has stripes that resemble the zebra. It lives in the Ituri Forest in the Democratic Republic of the Congo. Okapis eat the leaves and buds of trees they can reach. They also graze on grass and ferns and eat fruit. Okapis tend to be solitary animals and the mother gives birth to one offspring which continues to be dependent on the mother’s milk for six months. When they are four to five years old, they are mature and can breed, but only with other okapis.Which of the following statements is applicable to the okapi?I.Okapi is a hybrid of a giraffe and a zebraII.Okapi is an herbivoreIII.Okapi is its own speciesA.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I and III only
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Okapi is a herbivore(II)because it only eats plants. Okapi is a species(III)since it can interbreed and produce fertile offspring.They are not a hybrid of a giraffe and a zebra (I), even though they look like one.

list.title: Question 11
list.content: Which of the following statement(s) is/are true for the genome?I.The genome is all the genetic information of an organism.II.Genomes within a species are identical in size.III.Genomes within a species vary in base sequence.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme:
CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The genome is all the genetic information in an organism (Statement I). The base sequence can vary within a species due to single-nucleotide polymorphism (Statement III). Therefore,Choice Cis correct as it contains both true statements.Choice Ais incorrect as it only includes one true statement.
The size of the genome within a species can vary, this can be due to mutations, such as insertions and deletions, soStatement IIis not true.Choices BandDare, therefore, incorrect.

list.title: Question 12
list.content: Which statement(s) below are challenges associated with the biological species concept (BSC)?I.The BSC assumes reproductive isolation, but some species are reproductively isolated only in certain environments.II.Fossil species cannot be assessed using the BSC due to the lack of observable mating behaviour.III.The BSC relies on morphological features, which can vary widely within a species.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis true because reproductive isolation may be context-dependent (e.g. due to geography or behaviour), making it unclear whether two populations are separate species under BSC.Statement IIis true because the BSC depends on observing whether organisms can interbreed. This is impossible with fossils, which are studied based on morphology and location, not reproductive behaviour.Statement IIIis false because the BSC specifically does not define species based on morphology; that is the morphological species concept. BSC focuses instead on reproductive capability, so this is not a valid criticism of BSC.Choice Bis correct because it includes only the two trueStatements IandII.Choice Ais incorrect as it is missing the trueStatement II.Choices CandDare incorrect as they include the falseStatement III.

list.title: Question 13
list.content: How are the chromosomes in a karyogram ordered?A.\hspace{1em}By analogous pairsB.\hspace{1em}By number of genesC.\hspace{1em}By sizeD.\hspace{1em}By position of the centromeres
list.markScheme: CExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Cis correct because the chromosomes in a karyogram are ordered in homologous pairs from largest to smallest.Choice Ais incorrect because chromosomes are grouped in homologous pairs (one from each parent), not analogous pairs.Choice Bis incorrect because the number of genes on each chromosome is highly variable, and genes do not have a consistent length. Although the chromosomes are aligned with their centromeres in a karyogram, the question only asks about the order of the chromosomes, which is not dependent on centromere position; thus,Choice Dis also incorrect.

list.title: Question 14
list.content: The table shows the number of chromosomes found in the gametes of various species.SpeciesHaploid chromosome number (n)Parascaris equorum(horse threadworm)2Vicia faba(field bean)6Oryza sativa(rice)12Homo sapiens(human)23Pan troglodytes(chimpanzee)24Canis familiaris(dog)39What can be concluded from the data in the table?I.Diploid cells usually have an even number of chromosomes.II.Species with more chromosomes have a larger genome size.III.Humans are most closely related toPan troglodytes.A.\hspace{1em}I onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Choice Ais correct because diploid cells have an even number of chromosomes (Statement I) unless affected by errors such as non-disjunction. This can be obtained by doubling the haploid number in the table and recognising that an odd number of diploid chromosomes cannot be evenly distributed to form gametes.Statement IIis false because the number of chromosomes an organism has is not an accurate reflection of its genome size.Oryza sativa, for example, has a much larger genome than any of the other species in the table despite having fewer chromosomes.Statement IIIis false because although humans are closely related to chimpanzees, this cannot be concluded from the data in the table alone.Stipa spartea(porcupine grass), for example, has the same number of chromosomes as humans but is not closely related.Choices B, C, andDare incorrect because they contain one or more false statements.

list.title: Question 15
list.content: Outline the different uses of karyograms.[3]Distinguish between cells with haploid and diploid nuclei.[4]Compare and contrast different types of chromosomes.[8]

Anythreeof the following:→\ce{ -> }​karyograms are images of the chromosomes in an organism[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs of decreasing length OR Sex chromosomes are the 23rd pair in human karyograms[1]→\ce{ -> }​karyograms can be used to identify the sex of an individual[1]→\ce{ -> }​karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy, e.g. Down syndromeORPatau syndromeORKlinefelter syndrome[1]→\ce{ -> }​karyograms can be used to determine if a chromosome is missingORif part of a chromosome is missing[1][3 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Karyograms(✓\checkmark✓) are images of the chromosomes in an organism. In a karyogram, the pairs of homologous chromosomes are arranged in pairs ofdecreasing length(✓\checkmark✓). The sex chromosomes are shown as the 23rd pair in human karyograms.
Karyograms can be used to determine if an individual is a biologicalmale or female(✓\checkmark✓). Two X chromosomes are present in a human female cell, and one X chromosome and one Y chromosome are present in a human male cell.
Karyograms can be used to identify conditions caused by trisomy (three copies of a chromosome) e.g.Down syndrome, Patau syndrome, Edward’s syndrome and Klinefelter syndrome).Anyfourof the following:→\ce{ -> }​haploid nuclei have one set of chromosomes,ORone chromosome per typeWHEREASdiploid nuclei have two setsORtwo chromosomes of each type[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid nuclei have one allele for each geneWHEREASdiploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid nuclei in humans have 23 chromosomes, and diploid nuclei in humans have 46 chromosomesORany other valid species example[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid cells are usually gametesWHEREASdiploid cells are usually somatic cells[1]→\ce{ -> }​haploid cells are usually the result of meiosis,WHILEdiploid cells are usually the result of mitosis.[1][4 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:Haploid nuclei haveone set of chromosomes(✓\checkmark✓), whereas diploid nuclei have two sets of chromosomes.  For example, inhumans(✓\checkmark✓), gametes have 23 chromosomes, while somatic cells have 46 chromosomes. Haploid nuclei haveone allele for each gene, (✓\checkmark✓)  whereas diploid nuclei have two alleles for each gene. In humans, onlygametes(✓\checkmark✓)  have haploid nuclei, whereas the rest of the somatic cells have diploid nuclei.Anyeightof the following:→\ce{ -> }​(within one species) different chromosomes are composed of DNA molecules with different lengths[1]→\ce{ -> }​(within one species) different chromosomes have different numbers of genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​(within one species) different chromosomes have different typesORdifferent numbers of genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​both prokaryoticANDeukaryotic chromosomes contain DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins,WHILEeukaryotic and archaeal chromosomes are associated with proteins[1]→\ce{ -> }​prokaryotic chromosomes are looped molecules of DNA,WHILEeukaryotic chromosomes are linear molecules of DNA[1]→\ce{ -> }​BOTHautosomes and sex chromosomes contain genes[1]→\ce{ -> }​the human Y chromosome carries information mainly coding for male sex determination and development,WHILEthe X chromosome carries information for other body characteristics[1]→\ce{ -> }​there is only one pair of sex chromosomes,WHILEthere can be more than one pair of autosomes (in different species)[1]→\ce{ -> }​autosomes are pairs of homologous chromosomes of equal length,WHILEtwo sex chromosomes can be different lengths[1]→\ce{ -> }​chromosomes can be homologous and non-homologous[1]→\ce{ -> }​homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes of equal length carrying the same genes, but different alleles,WHILEnon-homologous chromosomes, carry different genes[1][8 mark maximum]Sample Answer‾\underline{\textrm{Sample Answer}}Sample Answer​:All chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes, but theydiffer in length(✓\checkmark✓) and in thenumber of genes(✓\checkmark✓) andtype of genes(✓\checkmark✓). Similarities and differences between prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomes: Both prokaryotic and eukaryotic chromosomescontain DNA(✓\checkmark✓). Bacterial chromosomes are not associated with proteins, but eukaryotic chromosomes areassociated with proteins(✓\checkmark✓). Prokaryotic chromosomes are looped, while eukaryotic chromosomes arelinear(✓\checkmark✓).Similarities and differences between autosomes and sex chromosomes:Both autosomes and sex chromosomes are made of DNA and contain genes. Autosomes are chromosomes that do not determine sex and do not have genes for sex-linked characteristics; sex chromosomes determine sex and have genes for sex-linked traits. There is one pair of sex chromosomes in a somatic nucleus, but there can bemore than one pair of autosomes(✓\checkmark✓) in a somatic nucleus. X and Y chromosomes are of different lengths, while autosomal homologous chromosome pairs areequal in length(✓\checkmark✓)Comparing non-homologous chromosomes and homologous chromosomes:Homologous chromosomes are pairs of chromosomes that have genes for the same characteristics and can have the same or different alleles. Non-homologous chromosomes have genes fordifferent characteristics(✓\checkmark✓).A quality mark is awarded if each part of the question (a, b, c) is answered to earn at least half of the points available, answers do not require re-reading to be understood, and there are almost no errors and little irrelevant information.[1]

list.title: Question 16
list.content: Which of the following statements explain why classifying diverging populations as species can be arbitrary?I.Traits may diverge at different rates in different populationsII.Some populations may remain reproductively compatible despite divergenceIII.Morphological changes always occur before genetic differences appearA.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II, and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Statement Iis true because, during speciation, some traits (e.g., behaviour, physiology, morphology) can evolve faster than others. This means two populations might look different but still interbreed, or might appear similar but already be reproductively isolated. Because divergence doesn’t follow a fixed pattern, deciding when to define them as separate species becomes subjective.Statement IIis true because Populations might develop noticeable differences in traits (such as colouration or mating calls), but still produce fertile offspring when they interbreed. According to the biological species concept, they’re technically the same species, but these differences can confuse classification.Statement IIIis false because often, the opposite is true. Genetic differences (mutations, allele frequency changes) may accumulate before any visible morphological change occurs. For example, two populations may look identical but carry distinct genetic markers and be reproductively isolated.Saying morphological change “always” comes first is incorrect and overly simplistic.Choice Ais correct because it includes only the two trueStatements IandII.Choices B, CandDare incorrect as they include the falseStatement III.

list.title: Question 20

list.title: Question 21
list.content: The table shows factors that can result in speciation. Which word is matched to the correct definition?WordDefinitionA.\hspace{1em}PolyploidyHaving two complete sets of chromosomesB.\hspace{1em}Sexual reproductionThe combining of genetic information from two individualsC.\hspace{1em}Reproductive isolationSpecies breeding to produce infertile offspringD.\hspace{1em}MutationsRandom changes to the amino acid sequence
list.markScheme: BExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:Sexual reproduction involves the fusion of gametes from two individuals, resulting in offspring with a combination of genetic material. This process increases genetic variation, which is essential for evolution and natural selection.Choice Bis the correct answer.Polyploidy occurs when an organism has more than two complete sets of chromosomes (e.g., triploid 3n, tetraploid 4n). The definition given in the table describes diploidy (2n), which is the standard chromosome number in most sexually reproducing organisms;Choice Aincorrect.Interbreeding between different species can sometimes produce infertile offspring, such as a horse × donkey = mule. This is an example of reproductive isolation because the hybrid offspring is sterile, preventing gene flow between the two species. However, because horses and donkeys are already separate species, this does not result in speciation—it simply reinforces their reproductive barrier. For reproductive isolation to lead to speciation, it must occur within a single species, preventing interbreeding between different populations.Choice Cis incorrect.Mutations are random changes in DNA sequences, not in the amino acid sequence;Choice Dis incorrect.

list.title: Question 25
list.content: The following table shows the approximate number of protein-encoding genes found in various species. What can be concluded from these findings?SpeciesApproximate number of protein-encoding genesDrosophila melanogaster(fruit fly)14,000Oryza sativa(rice)51,000Gallus gallus(chicken)20,000-23,000Homo sapiens(human)20,000-25,000I.The number of genes is not a good indicator of organism complexity.II.Chickens may have more genes than humans.III.The number of base pairs in the rice genome is greater than in the other species.A.\hspace{1em}I and II onlyB.\hspace{1em}II and III onlyC.\hspace{1em}I and III onlyD.\hspace{1em}I, II and III
list.markScheme: AExplanation‾\underline{\textrm{Explanation}}Explanation​:The number of genes found in a species does not serve as a good indicator of complexity (Statement I). If it did, the data here would suggest that chickens and humans are equally complex, and that rice is far more complex than either of them. Due to the overlapping ranges in the number of genes, it is entirely possible for chickens to have a greater number of genes than humans (Statement II). It is impossible to determine the size of the genome (measured in base pairs) of a species based on the number of genes it has. In reality, rice has far fewer base pairs than chickens or humans despite having approximately twice as many genes (Statement III).Choice Ais, therefore, correct.Choices B, C, andDare incorrect as they all containStatement III.

Cancer is characterised by significant genomic instability, leading to massive variations in genome size when compared to noncancerous cells.Explain how single-cell genome sequencing can be more useful than traditional genome sequencing for developing effective cancer treatments.[3]The diagram below depicts nanopore DNA sequencing technology.  This portable technology involves passing a single piece of DNA through a tiny pore in a membrane in an electrical field in a manner such that the current can reveal the DNA sequence.  This allows for the analysis of environmental DNA (eDNA), which consists of DNA fragments shed by organisms into their surroundings (e.g., skin cells, waste).
